action.action-desc: Mrs. Dingell (for herself and Mr. Bacon) submitted the following concurrent resolution; which was referred to the Committee on Energy and Commerce

form.official-title: Designating September 2025 as Gynecologic Cancers Awareness Month.

whereas.text: Whereas gynecologic cancers include cervical, ovarian, endometrial/uterine, vaginal, and vulvar cancers with the first 3 being the most common;
Whereas there are approximately 118,920 new cases of these cancers diagnosed and approximately 34,630 deaths from gynecologic cancers annually;
Whereas endometrial cancer is 1 of the few cancers with rising incidence and mortality rates;
Whereas endometrial and ovarian cancer rank fifth and sixth in cancer deaths among women, respectively;
Whereas symptoms are often vague or misunderstood, and there are no screening tests to identify endometrial and ovarian cancers before they progress to later stages;
Whereas cervical cancer is the only gynecologic cancer with a reliable screening test and is vaccine-preventable;
Whereas increased awareness of gynecologic cancers can lead to earlier diagnosis, followup with appropriate health professionals, and improved outcomes; and
Whereas the Foundation for Women’s Cancer and other organizations celebrate September 2025 as Gynecologic Cancers Awareness Month: Now, therefore, be it

paragraph.text: supports the designation of Gynecologic Cancers Awareness Month;
supports the goals and ideals of Gynecologic Cancers Awareness Month;
recognizes and affirms the commitment of the United States to reducing the burden of these cancers on women by—

subparagraph.text: promoting awareness about the causes, risks, and prevention of gynecologic cancers;
supporting research on gynecologic cancers; and
taking other steps to improve health outcomes associated with these cancers and reduce associated mortality; and

paragraph.text: encourages every person in the United States to learn about the risk for gynecologic cancers.
